## Summary

* Approximate Bayesian inference method using Laplace approximations and adaptive Gauss-Hermite quadrature 
* Motivated by an evidence synthesis model for small-area estimation of HIV indicators in sub-Saharan Africa
* Implemented as a part of the `aghq` package [@stringer2021implementing], allowing flexible use of the method for any model with a `TMB` C++ user template

<!-- 38761C -->

## The Naomi HIV model

* District-level model of HIV indicators [@eaton2021naomi] which synthesises data from household surveys, antenatal care (ANC) clincs, and routine service provision of antiretroviral therapy (ART)
  * Combining evidence from multiple data sources helps overcome the limitations of any one
* Yearly estimation process: model run interactively by country teams using a web-app
  * Figure \@ref(fig:fig1) illustrates the seven stages of using the app
* Inference conducted in minutes using empirical Bayes (EB) and a Gaussian approximation via Template Model Builder `TMB` [@kristensen2016tmb]
* It would take days to get accurate answers with MCMC via `tmbstan` [@monnahan2018no], and this is not practical in this setting
* Motivates looking for a fast, approximate approach, that takes uncertainty in hyperparameters into account

```{r fig1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='100%', fig.cap='Model fitting occurs interactively in stages, taken from `naomi.unaids.org`'}
knitr::include_graphics("fig1.png")
```

## Extended latent Gaussian models

* Latent Gaussian model (LGM) [@rue2009approximate]: three stage hierarchical model with observations $y$, Gaussian latent field $x$ and hyperparameters $\theta$
* In an LGM the conditional mean depends on exactly one structured additive predictor $\mu_i = g(\eta_i)$ with $g: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$
  * The `R-INLA` implementation of integrated nested Laplace approximations applies only to LGMs
* Extended latent Gaussian models (ELGM) remove this requirement such that $\mu_i = g(\eta_{\mathcal{J_i}})$ where $g_i: \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{J_i}|} \to \mathbb{R}$
* Naomi is an ELGM, not an LGM, because we model:
  * ANC indicators offset from household survey indicators
  * Incidence depending on prevalence and ART coverage
  * Observed data as aggregated finer processes
  * Individuals as possibly attending ART clinics outside their home district
* ELGM precision matrices less sparse than those of LGMs
* We extend work of @stringer2022fast in this setting to the challenging Naomi ELGM

## Inference procedure

* Laplace approximation: Integrate out variables using a Gaussian approximation to the denominator
$$
p(\theta, y) \approx \tilde p_\text{LA}(\theta, y) = \frac{p(y, x, \theta)}{\tilde p_\text{G}(x \, | \, \theta, y)} \Big\rvert_{x = \hat x(\theta)}
$$
where $\tilde p_\text{G}(x \, | \, \theta, y) = \mathcal{N}(x \, | \, \hat x(\theta), \mathbf{H}(\theta)^{-1})$
  * Use automatic differentiation via `CppAD` in `TMB`
* Adaptive Gauss-Hermite Quadrature:
$$
\int_\Theta p(\theta) \text{d} \theta \approx \lvert L \rvert \sum_{z \in \mathcal{Q}(m, k)} p(\hat \theta + Lz) \omega(z)
$$
where the Gauss-Hermite quadrature rule $z \in \mathcal{Q}(\dim(\theta), k)$ is adapted based upon the mode $\hat \theta = \text{argmax}_{\theta \in \Theta} p(\theta)$ and lower Cholesky $LL^\top = - \partial_\theta^2 \log p(\theta) \rvert_{\theta = \hat \theta}$ of the target
  * $k$ is the number of quadrature points per dimension
* Algorithm (called `adam` for now) summarized by Figure \@ref(fig:fig2)

## Application to Malawi data

```{r fig3, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='100%', fig.cap='Model outputs for adults 15-49 in January 2016.'}
knitr::include_graphics("fig3.png")
```

* Relatively small country but still a large model
  * $\text{dim}(x)$ is 491 and $\text{dim}(\theta)$ is 24
* Fit inference methods `TMB`, `aghq`, `adam` and `tmbstan`
* Figure \@ref(fig:fig3) illustrates example model outputs: HIV prevalence, ART coverage, HIV incidence, and number of new infections, at the district level

```{r fig4, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='100%', fig.cap='Inference reults and ECDF comparison for one $x_i$.'}
knitr::include_graphics("fig4.png")
```

* Compare inferences using Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) tests on hyperparameter, latent field, and output posterior marginals
* Figure \@ref(fig:fig4) illustrates the ECDF differences for one particular node in the model with $\text{KS}(\texttt{TMB}, \texttt{tmbstan}) = 0.09$ and $\text{KS}(\texttt{adam}, \texttt{tmbstan}) = 0.02$

## Future directions

* Scaling up the hyperparameter grid beyond EB, when any dense grid would be impractical ($k^{24}$ nodes)
  * Sparse grids
  * Dense grids on a subspace
* Add Laplace matrix algebra approximations [@wood2020simplified]
* More comprehensive inference comparisons
  * Maximum mean discrepancy
  * Pareto-smoothed importance sampling
